As a result, EU sanctions designations avoid making a specific link between a designated individual or entity and a state sponsor, even when, as in the case of the July 2020 Russian targets, some of the listed individuals may work on behalf of government agencies or may be government agencies themselves., Though attribution is also a sovereign political decision in the United States, the process is more straightforward—there is no need to wrangle the agreement of twenty-seven member states to attribute.\nIndependent of the political reasons for (not) attributing a cyberattack, not all jurisdictions are equally competent in their ability to attribute. States differ in their ability to identify technical and political indicators of compromise and use signals, human, and open-source intelligence to understand them. As one RAND Corporation report put it, “These capabilities may not be widespread globally, and very few countries are thought to possess sophisticated all-source capabilities.”\n## Information-sharing\nThe press releases that accompany sanctions designations sometimes contain important information about how malicious actors carry out their attacks. Though formal information-sharing mechanisms exist in both the United States and the European Union, many involve a\n “Treasury Sanctions North Korean State-Sponsored Malicious Cyber Groups,” U.S. Department of the Treasury.\n Botek, “European Union establishes a sanction regime for cyber-attacks.”\n Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/1125 of July 30, 2020, O.J. (246) 4.\n Researchers at the European Union Institute for Security Studies describe the threshold for placing responsibility for a cyber operation on a state as defined by two criteria: “the cyber operation is attributed to that state and constitutes an internationally wrongful act. To be attributable to that state, the operation must have been carried out by one of its organs or by another actor acting on its behalf. A cyber operation attributable to a state may constitute an internationally wrongful act if it violates a norm of international law.” See Patryk Pawlak, Thomas Biersteker, and François Delerue, *Guardian of the galaxy: EU cyber sanctions and norms in cyberspace*, eds. Patryk Pawlak and Thomas Biersteker (Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2019) 45, https://www.iss.europa.eu/sites/default/files/EUISSFiles/cp155.pdf.\n John Davis II, Benjamin Boudreaux, Jonathan William Welburn, Jair Aguirre, Cordaye Olgetree, Geoffrey McGovern, and Michael Chase, “Stateless Attribution: Toward International Accountability in Cyberspace,” RAND Corporation, 2017, 14-15, https://cyber-peace.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/RAND_RR2081.pdf.\n Ibid., 14.\n I thank Eric Lorber for highlighting this important point and the examples of the FinCEN Exchange and BSAAG.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nlimited set of stakeholders. In the United States, for example, the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) Exchange is a Treasury-led “voluntary public-private information sharing partnership among law enforcement, financial institutions, and FinCEN aimed at effectively and efficiently combating money laundering, terrorism financing, organized crime, and other financial crimes; protecting the financial system from illicit use; and promoting national security.” Additionally, the Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Group (BSAAG) is “the means by which Treasury receives advice on the operations of the Bank Secrecy Act,” a key piece of U.S. law regarding money laundering. Made of up representatives from federal agencies, financial institutions, and trade groups, BSAAG is chaired by the FinCEN director. Though these mechanisms are essential means of sharing information, the participating institutions and representatives are limited.\nHowever, public press releases can garner the attention of a broader set of stakeholders with sanctions compliance obligations and can aid in disseminating information related to cyber threats. For example, the United States’ designation of Nigerian cybercriminals contained details of how Richard Uzuh and his co-conspirators spoofed emails from business executives to trick Americans into wiring money.\n## Audience satisfaction\nSanctions may satisfy the political pressure to “do something” in response to malicious cyber activity. As Richard Hanania has argued, sanctions have a significant political purpose insofar as they “appear to be a moderate and measured response to unacceptable behavior abroad.” And they are a safe option for policymakers because the targets—foreign publics—cannot easily influence American politics (i.e., vote), and, therefore, “there is little reason to suspect that their\n Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, “FinCEN Exchange Questions and Answers,” U.S. Department of the Treasury, https://www.fincen.gov/index.php/resources/fincen-exchange/fincen-exchange-frequently-asked-questions.\n U.S. Department of the Treasury, Notice, “Financial Crimes Enforcement Network; Bank Secrecy Act Advisory Group; Solicitation of Application for Membership,” *Federal Register* 83, no. 248 (December 28, 2018): 67487, https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2018-12-28/pdf/2018-28178.pdf.\n Ibid.\n “Treasury Sanctions Nigerian Cyber Actors for Targeting U.S. Businesses and Individuals,” U.S. Department of the Treasury.\n William Kaempfer and Anton Lowenberg, “The Political Economy of Economic Sanctions,” in *Handbook of Defense Economics, Volume 2*, ed. Todd Sandler and Keith Hartley (Elsevier, 2007), 870, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1574001306020278?via%3Dihub.\n Richard Hanania, “Ineffective, Immoral, Politically Convenient: America’s Overreliance on Economic Sanctions and What to Do about It,” CATO Institute, February 18, 2020, https://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/ineffective-immoral-politically-convenient-americas-overreliance#sanctions-political-act.\n\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\ninterests will be protected or significantly taken into account.”\nWhere cybersecurity is specifically concerned, as Hinck and Maurer point out in their work on criminal charges, victims of malicious cyber activities may be partially satisfied by knowing the perpetrator’s identity and that the perpetrator has been held responsible. From the perspective of companies, it may help redirect blame from the company for failing to prevent a cyberattack.\nSanctions may also satisfy international audiences that want to see governments respond to malicious cyber activity. In some cases, sanctions are met with laudatory statements from allied governments. For example, the United States released such a message when the European Union imposed cyber sanctions for the first time in July 2020.\n## Cooperation with allies\nGiven that both the United States and European Union have legal frameworks to impose sanctions against malicious cyber actors, there is a potential cooperative dimension to the policy. Some have suggested that sanctions work better when there are concerted efforts among states to restrict an actor’s capabilities and deny its action’s benefits because it limits the actor’s ability to mitigate losses in other markets. Even without cooperative effort, sanctions can signal to members of the international community a shared commitment to reducing malicious activity. Where the cyber context is concerned, European action can have a particularly important signaling function given, as a former State Department official put it, the fact that actors like Russia and China are increasingly writing off signaling from the United States.\nThe U.S. and EU legal authorities are mostly similar, heightening the potential cooperative dimension. At their cores, both offer the ability to impose sanctions on individuals and entities that disrupt the confidentiality, availability, or integrity of data or the functioning of computer systems that support critical infrastructure or governmental services. And so far, U.S. and EU\n Ibid.\n Hinck and Maurer, “Persistent enforcement,” 531.\n Ibid.\n Michael Pompeo, “The United States Applauds the EU’s Action on Cyber Sanctions,” U.S. Department of State, Press release, July 30, 2020, https://www.state.gov/the-united-states-applauds-the-eus-action-on-cyber-sanctions/.\n Dursun Peksen, “When Do Economic Sanctions Work Best?” Center for a New American Security, June 10, 2019, https://www.cnas.org/publications/commentary/when-do-economic-sanctions-work-best.\n I thank a former U.S. Department of State official for making this observation.\n\ndesignations have largely overlapped: the United States has previously sanctioned six of the nine targets from the EU’s initial July 2020 listing.\n## Norm development\nBy clearly delineating unacceptable harms and imposing costs against those who perpetrate them, sanctions can underscore the importance of internationally recognized norms. Imposing sanctions in concert with like-minded nations further strengthens the norm development function. Having multiple states commit to punishing a malicious actor reinforces the wrongfulness of the act in question and helps establish what constitutes an appropriate state response to such wrongful behavior.\nIn his statement following the EU’s first cyber sanctions, High Representative Josep Borrell explicitly referenced commitment to implementing the norms developed by the UN Group of Government Experts’ (UNGGE) 2010, 2013, and 2015 reports and to continued cooperation the ongoing UNGGE and Open-Ended Working Group.\n## Punishment of malicious actors\nBy blocking transactions and freezing malicious cyber actors’ assets, policymakers demonstrate that engaging in offensive behavior has real financial consequences. Because many cyberattacks are financially motivated, sanctions deny the benefits of an actor’s behavior by making it more difficult to access and move money.\nGoldman has argued that targeted financial sanctions play a vital role in the broader effort to deter financially motivated cybercrime—especially cyber-enabled economic espionage—by “drying up the market for stolen data.” Since the United States’ sanctions framework allows for the designation of not just those who steal intellectual property but also those who benefit\n “Treasury Targets Russian Operatives over Election Interference, World Anti-Doping Agency Hacking, and Other Malign Activities,” U.S. Department of the Treasury; U.S. President, “Taking Additional Steps to Address the National Emergency With Respect to Significant Malicious Cyber-Enabled Activities,” 3; “Treasury Targets North Korea for Multiple Cyber-Attacks,” U.S. Department of the Treasury; Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/1125 of July 30, 2020, O.J. (246) 4.\n I thank Duncan Hollis for highlighting this point.\n Council of the EU, “Declaration by the High Representative Josep Borrell on behalf of the EU: European Union response to promote international stability in cyberspace.”\n Carlin, “Detect, Disrupt, Deter,” 420.\n Goldman and McCoy, “Deterring Financially Motivated Cybercrime,” 602.\n\nfrom the stolen information, threat of punishment can serve as a powerful incentive to abstain from wrongful behavior.\n## Disruption of capabilities\nSanctions also impose costs on adversary actors. By freezing assets and blocking transactions, sanctions can disrupt the financing of an offensive cyber operation. In theory, they can also disrupt a state’s ability to recruit the talent necessary to carry out a sophisticated operation—the exposure of a hacker’s identity and the financial punishment may dissuade would-be hackers from serving as a proxy.\nSanctions against terrorist financiers are an important precedent in this respect. In 2001, then-president George W. Bush signed Executive Order 13224 to allow for the imposition of sanctions against those determined “To assist in, sponsor, or provide financial, material, or technological support for, or financial or other services in support of, acts of terrorism.” According to Juan Zarate, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Terrorist Financing and Financial Crimes, the use of sanctions against terrorist organizations led to the development of additional horizontal sanctions programs to deal with behavior-based national security threats—like cyber threats. The logic of going after financing networks and enablers is simple: As Zachary Goldman has put it, “Entities like drug trafficking networks, terrorist groups, and proliferation facilitators require substantial streams of funding and access to the global financial system, to remain effective. The more time and resources they spend trying to fund an organization, the less time spent planning attacks or engaging in other illicit activity.”\n## Deterrence\nThrough the previously listed means, sanctions may aspire to a deterrent function that seeks to change state actors’ long-term behavior in cyberspace. The repeated imposition of sanctions may introduce sustained friction in the relationship between the proxy and the state that changes the state’s overall calculus about how and when to engage in malicious cyber activity. Over time, this may lead to a change in the nature of the state’s relationship with its proxies and the degree of risk it is willing to accept when engaging in offensive cyber operations. By punishing\n U.S. President, “Blocking the Property of Certain Persons Engaging in Significant Malicious Cyber-Enabled Activities,” 18077.\n Bureau of Counterterrorism, “Executive Order 13224,” U.S. Department of State, https://www.state.gov/executive-order-13224/.\n I thank former Assistant Secretary Zarate for highlighting this historical context.\n Zachary Goldman, “Cybersecurity and a New Era of Asymmetric Economic Warfare.”\n\ncountries that engage in offensive activity and demonstrating the international community’s support for this behavior, states can aim to increase the effort, raise the risk, and reduce offensive cyber actors’ rewards.\nDespite the difficulty, even for policymakers, of evaluating sanctions’ success at deterrence, they remain a tool often used for responding to malicious activity. Therefore, our understanding of the impact of sanctions must go beyond the deterrent function and consider the additional symbolic purposes outlined above and the factors that might also impact how symbolic goals are achieved. Table 2 summarizes questions policymakers might consider in evaluating the effectiveness of sanctions at achieving the variety of purposes set forward in this section and the considerations for assessing deterrence outlined in the previous section.\nTable 2. Questions for evaluating effectiveness\n|  Function | Questions  |\n| --- | --- |\n|  Attribution | • Do the statements accompanying a sanctions designation claim that the named entities perpetrated a cyberattack itself?\n• Do the statements accompanying a sanctions designation allege state responsibility for wrongful behavior in cyberspace?\n• Have other policies or legal action (i.e., indictments) made similar attribution claims?  |\n|  Information-sharing | • Do private sector entities pay attention to sanctions notices more than other vehicles for information-sharing about cyber threats?\n• Do the statements accompanying a sanctions designation contain meaningful information about the tactics, techniques, and procedures employed by malicious actors that external stakeholders could use to fortify their networks?  |\n|  Audience satisfaction | • Do actors in the private sector or civil society find sanctions a meaningful and appropriate response to malicious activity?\n• Do allies release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action?  |\n|  Cooperation with allies | • Do (or could) other jurisdictions impose sanctions against the same targets?\n• Do other countries release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action?  |\n|  Norm development | • Does the offense that prompted sanction violate an established norm of responsible behavior in cyberspace?  |\n Joseph Nye, Jr., “Deterrence and Dissuasion in Cyberspace,” *International Security* 41, no. 3 (Winter 2016/17): 56, https://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/pdf/10.1162/ISEC_a_00266.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\n- Have other countries or jurisdictions signaled that sanctions are the appropriate response to this type of norm violation?\n## Punishment\n- How exposed is the individual or entity to the U.S. dollar or the euro’s impact in global financial markets?\n- What is the monetary value of the transactions blocked or assets frozen as a result of the sanction?\n- Do opportunities exist for a designated actor to protect their assets or recoup their losses?\n## Disruption of capabilities\n- Do sanctions disrupt an actor’s ability to procure material, financial, or technological resources necessary to carry out malicious activity?\n- How do sanctions affect the willingness of proxies to engage with state sponsors of malicious cyber activity?\n- Do opportunities exist for actors to circumvent sanctions or mitigate their impact by using alternative financial architectures?\n## Deterrence\n- Over time, does the nature of a particular actor’s behavior in cyberspace change?\n- Do sanctions change the risk-calculus of those engaged in malicious cyber activity?\n- Over time, does the nature of malicious cyber activity in general change?\n## General\n- How might adversaries respond or retaliate to sanctions? What is the likelihood of the target engaging in retaliation, and what would the consequences of retaliation be?\n- Are the costs absorbed by the sender of sanctions proportionate to the costs imposed on targets?\n- What alternative policy options are available, and how do the effects of these tools compare to those of sanctions?\n- What might the long-term consequences be for the architecture of the global financial system?\nHaving discussed the eight purposes sanctions may seek to serve, the operational question remains whether policymakers clearly articulate these objectives and how they measure sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving any of these goals. Not all of the potential purposes of cyber sanctions writ large will be served by a single designation, nor should they be. Policymakers’ goals differ with respect to the variety of cyber threats. The aim of preventing low-level cybercrime like business email compromise scams is different from seeking to encourage states to rein in their proxies when conducting offensive cyber operations.\nNo matter which goals policymakers have in mind with a sanctions designation, they should keep in mind the considerations outlined above pertaining to alternative policy instruments and long-term consequences. Take, for example, the goal of audience satisfaction and the pressure to “do something” in response to malicious cyber activity: Escalation can undermine audience\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nsatisfaction if a greater number of private sector entities become the victims of cyberattacks in response to sanctions. And the repeated imposition of sanctions may have diminishing returns as far as satisfying audiences—if policymakers describe sanctions in deterrence terms, domestic audiences may be satisfied initially, but the continuation of activity may be interpreted as a sign of failure and lend itself to disappointment.\nThis section has outlined seven purposes in addition to deterrence that policymakers may have in mind when employing sanctions against malicious cyber actors. It is difficult to say whether sanctions deter. But despite the emphasis on deterrence in policy statements, sanctions can have important symbolic purposes that should factor into evaluations of sanctions programs.\n# Conclusion\nThe definitional issues highlighted at the beginning of this paper related to what constitutes malicious cyber activity and should be included within this paper’s scope and the variety of aims of sanctions can raise a question about whether it makes sense to speak of a country or jurisdiction’s “cyber policy” or consider cyber issues a facet of a broader foreign policy. Future research in this area should address how policy should deal with the distinction between “cyber” as a threat itself and as a means for accomplishing other ends like intelligence collection, economic competition, or control over domestic political spaces. The United States’ use, in particular, of a variety of different legal instruments—not just the cyber-specific sanctions framework—highlights the fact that cybercrime and national security threats require a variety of flexible tools. More clearly delineating how and why cyber activity crosses a line of acceptability is crucial to promoting responsible behavior in cyberspace and identifying appropriate mechanisms for responding to harms.\nMore empirical research is also needed in this area. Much of the academic literature on sanctions focuses on those levied against states and deals insufficiently with the success of sanctions against nonstate and proxy actors. $^{166}$ As transnational threats multiply and policymakers reach for sanctions in response, they should have a clear evidence base supporting their decision making.\nThough policymakers often emphasize the goal of deterrence, articulation of the considerations for evaluating the effectiveness of sanctions is scant, even among government actors with access to the full array of intelligence necessary to make such evaluations. Policymakers should consider a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure, actors’ motivations, and the role that\n$^{166}$ Peksen, “When Do Imposed Economic Sanctions Work?,” 7-8.\n\ntargets play in wrongful behavior in seeking to evaluate the likely outcomes of a sanctions designation and its effectiveness. Furthermore, questions of effectiveness also require attention to alternative policy options and long-term consequences.\nMoving beyond deterrence and cost imposition, the diversity of actors against which policymakers impose sanctions requires more nuanced thinking. In the absence of clear frameworks for evaluating effectiveness and relative pessimism about sanctions’ effectiveness, policymakers continue to reach for the tool. Therefore, our understanding of the purposes of sanctions should account for functions like attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, and punishment.\nDespite being hailed as ineffective by academic scholars, policymakers continue to employ sanctions. Data collected by the Center for a New American Security shows that the current U.S. administration is more than willing to sanction adversaries. Even though 2019 saw the fewest designations during the current administration, the yearly total was still more than those of any single year under the previous administration. And the EU’s recent implementation of its cyber sanctions framework for the first time indicates that neither is the policy tool falling out of favor abroad.\n Johnpatrick Imperiale, “Sanctions by the Numbers,” Center for a New American Security, February 27, 2020, https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/sanctions-by-the-numbers.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",

    "__preamble__": "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n# Countering Malicious Cyber Activity: Targeted Financial Sanctions\nNatalie Thompson*\nSince 2012 policymakers in the United States and Europe have imposed targeted financial sanctions against malicious cyber operators with the stated goal of deterring such activity. This draft paper provides an overview of the legal frameworks for sanctioning malicious cyber actors and the set of relevant sanctions imposed to date. Despite an emphasis on the goal of deterrence, both policymakers and academics have difficulty determining whether sanctions deter malicious cyber activity. Considering the continued use of cyber sanctions, this paper highlights key considerations for policymakers to evaluate whether sanctions can deter wrongful behavior in cyberspace.\nKeywords: sanctions, economic statecraft, cyber, deterrence, descriptive studies, policy evaluation\n*Research Assistant, Cyber Policy Initiative, Technology and International Affairs Program, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Washington, DC, USA\nContact: thompsonr.natalie@gmail.com\nSpecial thanks go to my colleagues—especially Tim Maurer, George Perkovich, Jon Bateman, Ariel Levite, and Arthur Nelson—for supporting this research. Thanks also to Michael Daniel, Martha Finnemore, Duncan Hollis, Eric Lorber, Teddy Nemeroff, Patryk Pawlak, Allison Peters, Sverrir Steinsson, Juan Zarate, and a former U.S. Department of State official for their detailed feedback on the draft. Finally, thanks to the team at EU Cyber Direct for providing the opportunity to present an earlier draft of the paper at the 2020 Closing the Gap International Conference on Cyber, Digital, and Tech and to the conference participants for their thoughtful questions and comments. This draft reflects developments through October 2020 when it was finalized. All errors and omissions are the author's alone.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]",
    "# Introduction": "Cyberattacks targeting public and private entities have increased dramatically over the last decade.¹ Cyberspace is also increasingly a domain of geopolitical conflict. State (and non-state) actors are acquiring offensive cyber capabilities and have demonstrated a willingness to use them—states have conducted at least 358 hostile cyber operations² since 2005, more than half of which have occurred since 2017.³\nThe increasing number of attacks puts pressure on governments to counter malicious cyber activity and to promote norms of responsible behavior in cyberspace. States have relied on a mix of diplomatic, informational, economic, and law enforcement options to respond to malicious cyber activity. Some refer to these tools as the DIME(LE) set of instruments available to states seeking to influence others’ behavior.⁴,⁵\nSanctions are part of a state’s arsenal. Both the United States and the European Union have created specific authorities for targeted financial sanctions in response to malicious cyber activity⁶—referred to throughout this paper as “cyber sanctions.”⁷ The United States has imposed\n¹ The Center for Strategic and International Studies maintains a list of significant cyberattacks that have occurred since 2006, and the Council on Foreign Relations maintains an interactive tracker of offensive cyber operations perpetrated by states. See: “Significant Cyber Incidents,” Center for Strategic and International Studies, last updated April 2020, https://www.csis.org/programs/technology-policy-program/significant-cyber-incidents; “Cyber Operations Tracker,” Council on Foreign Relations, https://www.cfr.org/interactive/cyber-operations.\n² The Council on Foreign Relations uses the term “operations” to refer to 1) denial of service; 2) espionage; 3) data destruction; 4) defacement; 5) sabotage; 6) doxing; and 7) financial theft. See “Cyber Operations Tracker,” Council on Foreign Relations.\n³ Patryk Pawlak, Eneken Tikk, and Mika Kerttunen, “Cyber Conflict Uncoded,” European Union Institute for Security Studies, April 2020, https://www.iss.europa.eu/sites/default/files/EUISSFiles/Brief%207_Cyber.pdf.\n⁴ The DIME(LE) model is one method of categorizing these tools. A variety of others are used within the United States military to categorize and describe the operational environment; these include: 1) diplomatic, informational, military, and economic (DIME); 2) diplomatic, informational, military, economic, financial, intelligence, law enforcement (DIMEFIL); and 3) political, military, economic, social, informational, infrastructure (PMESII), among others. See Jack D. Kem, “Understanding the Operational Environment: The Expansion of DIME,” *Military Intelligence Professional Bulletin* 33, no. 2 (April – June 2007): 49-53, https://fas.org/irp/agency/army/mipb/2007_02.pdf.\n⁵ Tim Maurer, *Cyber Mercenaries: The State, Hackers, and Power* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2018), 139.\n⁶ U.S. Department of State, “Cyber Sanctions,” n.d., https://www.state.gov/cyber-sanctions/, accessed January 20, 2020; Council of the EU, “Cyber-attacks: Council is now able to impose sanctions,” Press release, May 17, 2019, https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2019/05/17/cyber-attacks-council-is-now-able-to-impose-sanctions/.\n⁷ This use of the term “cyber sanctions” is distinct from that of those who use it to refer to from the use of cyberattacks as a coercive method employed to “sanction” the wrongful behavior of adversaries or to achieve coercive economic ends. For a discussion on this topic, see: Marco Benatar and Kristof Gombeer, “Cyber Sanctions: Exploring a Blind Spot in the Current Legal Debate,” European Society of International Law Conference Paper\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nsanctions in response to malicious cyber activity thirty-five times over the past decade, and the European Union and the United Kingdom imposed similar sanctions for the first time in July 2020⁸ and again in October 2020.⁹\nScholars have long debated the effectiveness of sanctions generally and their ability to achieve policy aims.¹⁰ To evaluate the efficacy of cyber sanctions, one must first articulate the goals of sanctions and what they might be useful for achieving. Once policymakers answer questions of effectiveness, they can then craft their use of sanctions to best address relevant threats in cyberspace.\nThe diversity of malicious behavior in cyberspace makes it difficult to identify a coherent logic for using sanctions. States conduct offensive cyber operations in service of political goals while criminals engage in hacking for profit—sometimes, the two occur alongside one another.¹¹ The use of proxies in cyberspace complicates efforts to distinguish politically motivated and financially motivated attacks and obscures the relationship between state and non-state actors.¹²\nFurther compounding the problem are questions related to the harms that should be included in the definition of “malicious cyber activity.” Narrow definitions of “cyberattack” use the term to\nSeries, Conference Paper No. 9/2011, May 1, 2011, https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1989786 and Zachary Goldman, “Cybersecurity and a New Era of Asymmetric Economic Warfare,” Just Security, January 16, 2015, https://www.justsecurity.org/19150/cybersecurity-era-asymmetric-economic-warfare/.\n⁸ Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/1125 of July 30, 2020, implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/796 concerning restrictive measures against cyber-attacks threatening the Union or its Member States, 2020 O.J. (246) 4, https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32020R1125&amp;from=EN; “Foreign Secretary welcomes first EU sanctions against malicious cyber actors,” United Kingdom Foreign Office, July 30, 2020, https://www.gov.uk/government/news/foreign-secretary-welcomes-first-eu-sanctions-against-malicious-cyber-actors.\n⁹ Council of the EU, “Malicious cyber-attacks: EU sanctions two individuals and one body over 2015 Bundestag hack,” Press release, October 22, 2020, https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/10/22/malicious-cyber-attacks-eu-sanctions-two-individuals-and-one-body-over-2015-bundestag-hack/; “UK enforces new sanctions against Russia for cyber attack on German Parliament,” United Kingdom Foreign Office, October 22, 2020, https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-enforces-new-sanctions-against-russia-for-cyber-attack-on-german-parliament.\n¹⁰ Dursun Peksen, “When Do Imposed Economic Sanctions Work? A Critical Review of the Sanctions Effectiveness Literature,” Defence and Peace Economics 30, no. 6 (May 2019): 1-13, https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10242694.2019.1625250.\n¹¹ Juan Zarate, “The Cyber Financial Wars on the Horizon: The Convergence of Financial and Cyber Warfare and the Need for a 21st Century National Security Response,” Foundation for Defense of Democracies, July 2015, 5, https://assets.aspeninstitute.org/content/uploads/2016/05/Cyber_Financial_Wars.pdf.\n¹² For a comprehensive overview of the use of proxies in offensive cyber operations, see Maurer, Cyber Mercenaries.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nrefer to compromises in data confidentiality, integrity, or availability.¹³ But cyber tools can be used to engage in other wrongful behavior that falls outside of this framework. As a policy matter, the United States has used its cyber sanctions framework to punish behavior like election interference.¹⁴ Both the European Union and the United States have used human rights-related programs to respond to cyber-enabled human rights violations.¹⁵ As a result, this paper looks beyond sanctions frameworks meant explicitly to deal with malicious cyber activity and includes instances when additional horizontal frameworks have been used to respond to wrongful uses of information and communications technologies.\nThis paper seeks to provide an overview of targeted financial sanctions for countering malicious cyber activity in the United States and Europe and considerations regarding the tool’s effectiveness. Although policymakers often highlight deterrence and cost imposition as critical goals, both academic literature and policy documents point to difficulty measuring sanctions’ success at achieving these aims.\nThe continued reliance on the tool suggests that policymakers have other motivations for responding to malicious cyber activity with sanctions, regardless of whether sanctions are effective or whether their effectiveness can be measured. Part outlines the definitional issues related to the scope of “malicious cyber activity” and what, therefore, constitutes a “cyber sanction.” It then provides an overview of the designations to date in the United States and Europe. Part two discusses how policymakers and academics evaluate sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving often-touted deterrence goals and specific considerations related to policy alternatives and long-term consequences. Policymakers cannot ignore the alternative instruments available to respond to malicious cyber activity in thinking about effectiveness and must weigh the trade-offs associated with alternative responses to cyberattacks. Finally, policymakers cannot ignore how firms and other states respond to and perceive the credibility of U.S. sanctions in the long-run—both as it relates to their imposition and removal (or lack thereof). They must consider the corresponding implications for the architecture of the global financial system and United States’ ability to weaponize its financial position. Part three then offers a categorization of the different purposes that sanctions can serve beyond deterrence. These purposes include attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, punishment, and disruption of capabilities—all of which contribute cumulatively to the overarching goal of deterrence.",
    "## Defining “cyber sanctions”": "### What do sanctions entail?\nThe United States and EU’s cyber sanctions are targeted sanctions that differ from sanctions imposed during and before the 1990s. Comprehensive trade sanctions were a popular instrument of economic coercion throughout the 20th century, in part because they are less costly, less risky, and more palatable than military action. Targeted sanctions differ from comprehensive ones in coercive logic, the intended target, and the ultimate goal. Though similarly aimed at eliciting a change in state behavior, they focus on specific individuals and entities rather than the population at large.¹⁶ They assume that singling out individuals or groups will better “raise the target regime’s costs of noncompliance.”¹⁷ Targeted sanctions can also aim to change the\n¹⁶ Arne Tostensen and Beate Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” World Politics 53, no. 3 (April 2002): 380, 382.\n¹⁷ Daniel Drezner, “How Smart Are Smart Sanctions?” International Studies Review 5, no. 1 (March 2003): 107; see also Tostensen and Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” 380, 386; Thomas G. Weiss, “Sanctions as a Foreign Policy Tool: Weighing Humanitarian Impulses,” Journal of Peace Research 36, no. 5 (September 1999): 503; Daniel Drezner, “Sanctions Sometimes Smart: Targeted Sanctions in Theory and Practice,” International Studies Review 13, no. 1 (March 2011): 96, https://www.jstor.org/stable/23016144; and Daniel Drezner, “Targeted\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nbehavior of the targeted individuals or organizations themselves, making them useful tools for dealing with non-state actors and treating cases in which states employ proxies to accomplish their goals.¹⁸\nFurther, while comprehensive sanctions often aim to change policy or behavior — and sometimes, explicitly or implicitly, wholesale regime change¹⁹—scholars studying targeted sanctions recognize their utility for achieving more modest policy goals. Targeted sanctions are understood to have additional value for constraining and signaling. By “constraining,” these scholars refer to complicating an actor’s ability to engage in internationally wrongful behavior.²⁰ By “signaling,” they refer to sending a message to the target, domestic audiences, and international audiences that expresses support for norms of appropriate behavior.²¹\nOne type of targeted sanction, restrictive financial measures (also referred to as targeted financial sanctions), is increasingly the tool of choice for policymakers seeking to impose consequences for internationally wrongful behavior. Targeted financial sanctions include asset freezes, blocking transactions with designated individuals or entities, and denying access to capital markets.²² The tool relies on the preeminence of certain currencies and jurisdictions in global financial transactions.²³ Big financial players like the United States, Europe, and, to a lesser extent, China can weaponize the financial system to prevent specific individuals or organizations from transacting in their respective currencies. The existence of “chokepoints” in the financial system that gives western states (particularly the United States) the “capacity to limit or penalize use of hubs by third parties (e.g., other states or private actors)” is a source of “considerable coercive power.” See Henry Farrell and Abraham Newman, “Weaponized Interdependence,” International Security 44, no. 1 (Summer 2019): 55-56.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nforeign policy emanating from these jurisdictions is incomplete without attention to the potential uses of targeted financial sanctions.²⁴",
    "## Definitional issues": "The first issue to address in defining “cyber sanctions” is related to what constitutes “malicious cyber activity” and which sanctions should, therefore, be considered within this paper’s scope.\nIn April 2015, then-U.S. president Barack Obama created the first targeted financial sanctions framework meant to deal specifically with cyber-related harms;²⁵ the Europeans followed suit in 2019;²⁶ and the United Kingdom finalized their cyber sanctions regulation earlier this year.²⁷ The United States, EU, and UK authorities relate principally to compromises in data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.²⁸\nThese cyber-specific frameworks, however, do not tell the whole story. (68) 12-13, https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32013R0206&amp;from=EN.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nsanctions.³⁰ And the United States has used its cyber-specific framework and a different election interference framework to punish Russian cyber-enabled influence operators.³¹\nThese Iran- and Russia-linked cases are somewhat ambiguous as to whether or not they constitute cyber-enabled harms that should be included in this paper. They do not fit neatly into the definition of cyberattack promulgated by the U.S. National Institute of Technology and Standards: “An attack, via cyberspace, targeting an enterprise’s use of cyberspace for the purpose of disrupting, disabling, destroying, or maliciously controlling a computing environment/infrastructure; or destroying the integrity of the data or stealing controlled information.”³² For example, monitoring dissidents or using social media to promote narratives online does not necessarily compromise data confidentiality, integrity, or availability. Still, the United States and Europe have considered them harmful enough uses of information and communications technologies to warrant punishment. For this reason, sanctions falling under the cyber-specific framework, as well as others related to cyber-enabled influence operations and human rights violations, are included within the scope of this paper.",
    "## “Cyber sanctions” to date": "With these definitional concerns in mind, this section provides a brief overview of the cyber sanctions imposed to date in both the United States and Europe.\nExecutive Order 13694, which created the United States’ cyber-specific sanctions framework, “declare[d] a national emergency with respect to the unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, foreign policy, and economy of the United States posed by the increasing prevalence and severity of malicious cyber-enabled activities originating from or directed by, persons located, in whole or in substantial part, outside the United States.”³³\nSo far, the United States has imposed thirty-five tranches of sanctions related to malicious cyber activity under both the cyber-specific framework and other country-specific and horizontal\n³⁰ For example, the EU sanctioned Abdolsamad Khoramabadi, head of the Committee to Determine Instances of Criminal Content, in March 2013, and the United States later imposed sanctions in May 2018. See: Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2013/206 of March 11, 2013, 2013 O.J. (68) 12-13; “Treasury Targets Human Rights Abuses, Censorship, and Enhanced Monitoring by the Iranian Government,” U.S. Department of the Treasury, May 30, 2018, https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm0397.\n³¹ For example: “Treasury Sanctions Russian Cyber Actors for Interference with the 2016 U.S. Elections and Malicious Cyber-Attacks,” U.S. Department of the Treasury.\n³² Computer Security Resource Center, “Cyber Attack.”\n³³ Office of the Press Secretary, “FACTSHEET: Executive Order Blocking the Property of Certain Persons Engaging in Significant Malicious Cyber-Enabled Activities,” White House, April 1, 2015, https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/04/01/fact-sheet-executive-order-blocking-property-certain-persons-engaging-si.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nsanctions frameworks. These designations involve entities linked to Iran, North Korea, Russia, China, and Nigeria. The earliest designations, dating back to 2012 (made under an Executive Order on terrorism-related sanctions), dealt with Iranian government officials and entities participating in computer hacking projects with Hezbollah.³⁴ Since then, the United States has sanctioned a range of cybercriminals and nation-state hackers. These include North Korean actors that participated in the 2014 hack of Sony Pictures, Russian actors engaged in cyber-enabled election interference, and Iranian actors targeting U.S. financial institutions.³⁵ Since 2012, the United States has sanctioned over 250 individuals and entities for engaging in or enabling malicious cyber activity. (For a complete list of incidents, see Table 1.) The majority have been of Iranian, Russian, or North Korean origin. In the first half of 2020, however, the United States took action against two Chinese nationals for aiding Lazarus Group’s efforts to launder money, as well as six Nigerian individuals engaged in business email compromise and romance fraud scams.³⁶\nIn statements on the Executive Order, policymakers highlighted the “significant increase in the frequency, scale, and sophistication of cyber incidents targeting the American people” to justify its signing.³⁷ Absent in many of these statements are clear articulations of how the administration would evaluate these sanctions’ effectiveness. In a blog post following the signing of the April 2015 Executive Order, White House counterterrorism advisor Lisa Monica explained that policymakers hoped to “deter” and “impose costs” on adversaries.³⁸ But the specific means by which the U.S. Department of the Treasury would evaluate the program’s effectiveness remain unclear.     "## Do cyber sanctions deter?": "As described above, policymakers in both the United States and European Union emphasize that cyber sanctions aim to deter malicious actors and behavior. As Zachary Goldman and Damon McCoy have pointed out, “different kinds of malicious cyber activity demand different, tailored, deterrence strategies. This is because each category of cyber threat has a different motivation, and therefore will be sensitive to a different type of cost.”51 Nation-state hackers with political goals are unlikely to suffer the same consequences of a sanctions designation that independent cybercriminals with financial motivations will suffer. Similarly, designating a government official orchestrating an attack is unlikely to have the same impact as designating an individual two or three steps removed that launders money on behalf of a hacking group.\nTwo things complicate the effort to neatly distinguish between categories like cybercrime and nation-state activity and state and non-state actors. First, the convergence of financially-motivated cybercrime and nation-state activity makes it difficult to separate cyberattacks conducted for purely economic gain and those undertaken for political purposes.52 North Korean efforts to raise funds for its weapons of mass destruction program through cyber theft and ransom operations against financial institutions and cryptocurrency exchanges have demonstrated the difficulty of separating financial motivations from political goals.53 Similarly, state-sponsored economic espionage emanating from China blurs the distinction between financial and political aims as the theft of intellectual property aims to “support its strategic development goals—science and technology advancement, military modernization, and economic policy objectives.”54\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nSecond, the use of proxies for conducting offensive cyber operations often precludes a neat division between state and non-state actors in cyberspace. Tim Maurer’s comprehensive overview of the use of proxies for accomplishing offensive cyber operations details the spectrum of relationships between states and their proxies.⁵⁵ These relationships range from overt delegation of activity to loose orchestration to passive enablement of proxy behavior. In the latter cases, those operating at a state’s behest may also have a foot in the criminal world. For example, in 2019, Treasury alleged that a Russian cybercriminal indicted and sanctioned for developing and distributing malware also operated on behalf of the Russian government, “highlighting the Russian government’s enlistment of cybercriminals for its own malicious purposes.”⁵⁶",
    "## Evaluating effectiveness": "It is not within the remit of external observers to assess whether cyber sanctions effectively achieve deterrence. Much of the information needed to make such an assessment is classified or privately owned intelligence. Though Treasury publicly reports the value of transactions blocked under specific sanctions programs, others have pointed out that evaluating the success of cyber sanctions based on the financial value of prevented transactions is misleading.⁵⁷ Therefore, it is difficult for policymakers to attribute any observed decrease in malicious cyber activity or change in activity to sanctions or determine whether activity levels would be even greater absent the threat of sanctions or imposition.\nWithin the U.S. government, Treasury’s Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) and the State Department’s Bureau of Intelligence and Research perform impact assessments.⁵⁸ According to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), which published a review of U.S. sanctions programs and their effectiveness in 2019, “These assessments analyze the impacts of specific sanctions on a particular aspect of the sanction’s target—for example, the sanctions’ impact on the target country’s economy or trade.”⁵⁹ OIA, for example, conducts impact assessments before a sanctions designation and after its imposition and may include factors like the target’s U.S.-\n⁵⁵ Maurer, *Cyber Mercenaries*, assessments:\nAccording to OIA officials, assessing impact is analyzing the potential or observed effect of the sanction on the target. According to officials, impact can be focused on a singular target or could be broader, such as the impact on the target country’s economy or trade flows. In contrast, OIA views effectiveness as the extent to which a sanctions program is achieving the overall broader policy goals of the sanctions program, such as ultimately altering or deterring specific behaviors of the target or furthering U.S. national security priorities [Emphasis added].⁶²\nThe latter considerations come into play during National Security Council-led interagency discussions: The process “allows the U.S. government to draw upon multiple agencies’ inputs and perspectives, and to consider these issues in the larger policy context, because sanctions are often only one element of broader government-wide strategies to achieve U.S. policy goals.”⁶³\nEven within government, assessing the effectiveness of sanctions at achieving broader policy goals like deterrence is difficult. GAO’s report highlights that policymakers have difficulty isolating sanctions’ effects from those of other policy tools, dealing with shifting policy objectives, and identifying useful data for conducting assessments.⁶⁴\nThe threat of sanctions raises an additional challenge for evaluating effectiveness.⁶⁵ In at least one notable instance pertaining to Chinese cyber-enabled economic espionage, U.S. threats to impose sanctions may have contributed to the signing of a diplomatic agreement between then-\n⁶⁰ Ibid., 13-14.\n⁶¹ Ibid., 12.\n⁶² Ibid.\n⁶³ Ibid., 12.\n⁶⁴ Ibid., 17-18.\n⁶⁵ See, for example, Daniel Drezner’s work on selection bias in evaluations of sanctions programs, which suggests that sanctions are more effective than most analyses contend because they miss instances in which sanctions are threatened but not imposed: “in focusing only on those instances when sanctions have been imposed, policy analysts have overlooked the significant number of instances in which the threat of coercion did not have to be carried out.” Daniel Drezner, “The Hidden Hand of Economic Coercion,” International Organization 57, no. 3 (June 2003): 654-655, https://doi.org/10.1017/S0020818303573052.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\npresident Obama and President Xi.
