 |\n|  Audience satisfaction | • Do actors in the private sector or civil society find sanctions a meaningful and appropriate response to malicious activity?\n• Do allies release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action?  |\n|  Cooperation with allies | • Do (or could) other jurisdictions impose sanctions against the same targets?\n• Do other countries release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action?  |\n|  Norm development | • Does the offense that prompted sanction violate an established norm of responsible behavior in cyberspace?  |\n Joseph Nye, Jr., “Deterrence and Dissuasion in Cyberspace,” *International Security* 41, no. 3 (Winter 2016/17): 56, https://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/pdf/10.1162/ISEC_a_00266.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\n- Have other countries or jurisdictions signaled that sanctions are the appropriate response to this type of norm violation?\n## Punishment\n- How exposed is the individual or entity to the U.S. dollar or the euro’s impact in global financial markets?\n- What is the monetary value of the transactions blocked or assets frozen as a result of the sanction?\n- Do opportunities exist for a designated actor to protect their assets or recoup their losses?\n## Disruption of capabilities\n- Do sanctions disrupt an actor’s ability to procure material, financial, or technological resources necessary to carry out malicious activity?\n- How do sanctions affect the willingness of proxies to engage with state sponsors of malicious cyber activity?\n- Do opportunities exist for actors to circumvent sanctions or mitigate their impact by using alternative financial architectures?\n## Deterrence\n- Over time, does the nature of a particular actor’s behavior in cyberspace change?\n- Do sanctions change the risk-calculus of those engaged in malicious cyber activity?\n- Over time, does the nature of malicious cyber activity in general change?\n## General\n- How might adversaries respond or retaliate to sanctions? What is the likelihood of the target engaging in retaliation, and what would the consequences of retaliation be?\n- Are the costs absorbed by the sender of sanctions proportionate to the costs imposed on targets?\n- What alternative policy options are available, and how do the effects of these tools compare to those of sanctions?\n- What might the long-term consequences be for the architecture of the global financial system?\nHaving discussed the eight purposes sanctions may seek to serve, the operational question remains whether policymakers clearly articulate these objectives and how they measure sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving any of these goals. Not all of the potential purposes of cyber sanctions writ large will be served by a single designation, nor should they be. Policymakers’ goals differ with respect to the variety of cyber threats. The aim of preventing low-level cybercrime like business email compromise scams is different from seeking to encourage states to rein in their proxies when conducting offensive cyber operations.\nNo matter which goals policymakers have in mind with a sanctions designation, they should keep in mind the considerations outlined above pertaining to alternative policy instruments and long-term consequences. Take, for example, the goal of audience satisfaction and the pressure to “do something” in response to malicious cyber activity: Escalation can undermine audience\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nsatisfaction if a greater number of private sector entities become the victims of cyberattacks in response to sanctions. And the repeated imposition of sanctions may have diminishing returns as far as satisfying audiences—if policymakers describe sanctions in deterrence terms, domestic audiences may be satisfied initially, but the continuation of activity may be interpreted as a sign of failure and lend itself to disappointment.\nThis section has outlined seven purposes in addition to deterrence that policymakers may have in mind when employing sanctions against malicious cyber actors. It is difficult to say whether sanctions deter. But despite the emphasis on deterrence in policy statements, sanctions can have important symbolic purposes that should factor into evaluations of sanctions programs.\n# Conclusion\nThe definitional issues highlighted at the beginning of this paper related to what constitutes malicious cyber activity and should be included within this paper’s scope and the variety of aims of sanctions can raise a question about whether it makes sense to speak of a country or jurisdiction’s “cyber policy” or consider cyber issues a facet of a broader foreign policy. Future research in this area should address how policy should deal with the distinction between “cyber” as a threat itself and as a means for accomplishing other ends like intelligence collection, economic competition, or control over domestic political spaces. The United States’ use, in particular, of a variety of different legal instruments—not just the cyber-specific sanctions framework—highlights the fact that cybercrime and national security threats require a variety of flexible tools. More clearly delineating how and why cyber activity crosses a line of acceptability is crucial to promoting responsible behavior in cyberspace and identifying appropriate mechanisms for responding to harms.\nMore empirical research is also needed in this area. Much of the academic literature on sanctions focuses on those levied against states and deals insufficiently with the success of sanctions against nonstate and proxy actors. $^{166}$ As transnational threats multiply and policymakers reach for sanctions in response, they should have a clear evidence base supporting their decision making.\nThough policymakers often emphasize the goal of deterrence, articulation of the considerations for evaluating the effectiveness of sanctions is scant, even among government actors with access to the full array of intelligence necessary to make such evaluations. Policymakers should consider a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure, actors’ motivations, and the role that\n$^{166}$ Peksen, “When Do Imposed Economic Sanctions Work?,” 7-8.\n\ntargets play in wrongful behavior in seeking to evaluate the likely outcomes of a sanctions designation and its effectiveness. Furthermore, questions of effectiveness also require attention to alternative policy options and long-term consequences.\nMoving beyond deterrence and cost imposition, the diversity of actors against which policymakers impose sanctions requires more nuanced thinking. In the absence of clear frameworks for evaluating effectiveness and relative pessimism about sanctions’ effectiveness, policymakers continue to reach for the tool. Therefore, our understanding of the purposes of sanctions should account for functions like attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, and punishment.\nDespite being hailed as ineffective by academic scholars, policymakers continue to employ sanctions. Data collected by the Center for a New American Security shows that the current U.S. administration is more than willing to sanction adversaries. Even though 2019 saw the fewest designations during the current administration, the yearly total was still more than those of any single year under the previous administration. And the EU’s recent implementation of its cyber sanctions framework for the first time indicates that neither is the policy tool falling out of favor abroad.\n Johnpatrick Imperiale, “Sanctions by the Numbers,” Center for a New American Security, February 27, 2020, https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/sanctions-by-the-numbers.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",

      "flat_text": "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n# Countering Malicious Cyber Activity: Targeted Financial Sanctions\nNatalie Thompson*\nSince 2012 policymakers in the United States and Europe have imposed targeted financial sanctions against malicious cyber operators with the stated goal of deterring such activity. This draft paper provides an overview of the legal frameworks for sanctioning malicious cyber actors and the set of relevant sanctions imposed to date. Despite an emphasis on the goal of deterrence, both policymakers and academics have difficulty determining whether sanctions deter malicious cyber activity. Considering the continued use of cyber sanctions, this paper highlights key considerations for policymakers to evaluate whether sanctions can deter wrongful behavior in cyberspace.\nKeywords: sanctions, economic statecraft, cyber, deterrence, descriptive studies, policy evaluation\n*Research Assistant, Cyber Policy Initiative, Technology and International Affairs Program, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Washington, DC, USA\nContact: thompsonr.natalie@gmail.com\nSpecial thanks go to my colleagues—especially Tim Maurer, George Perkovich, Jon Bateman, Ariel Levite, and Arthur Nelson—for supporting this research. Thanks also to Michael Daniel, Martha Finnemore, Duncan Hollis, Eric Lorber, Teddy Nemeroff, Patryk Pawlak, Allison Peters, Sverrir Steinsson, Juan Zarate, and a former U.S. Department of State official for their detailed feedback on the draft. Finally, thanks to the team at EU Cyber Direct for providing the opportunity to present an earlier draft of the paper at the 2020 Closing the Gap International Conference on Cyber, Digital, and Tech and to the conference participants for their thoughtful questions and comments. This draft reflects developments through October 2020 when it was finalized. All errors and omissions are the author's alone.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\n# Introduction\nCyberattacks targeting public and private entities have increased dramatically over the last decade. Cyberspace is also increasingly a domain of geopolitical conflict. State (and non-state) actors are acquiring offensive cyber capabilities and have demonstrated a willingness to use them—states have conducted at least 358 hostile cyber operations since 2005, more than half of which have occurred since 2017.\nThe increasing number of attacks puts pressure on governments to counter malicious cyber activity and to promote norms of responsible behavior in cyberspace. States have relied on a mix of diplomatic, informational, economic, and law enforcement options to respond to malicious cyber activity. Some refer to these tools as the DIME(LE) set of instruments available to states seeking to influence others’ behavior.,\nSanctions are part of a state’s arsenal. Both the United States and the European Union have created specific authorities for targeted financial sanctions in response to malicious cyber activity—referred to throughout this paper as “cyber sanctions.” The United States has imposed\n The Center for Strategic and International Studies maintains a list of significant cyberattacks that have occurred since 2006, and the Council on Foreign Relations maintains an interactive tracker of offensive cyber operations perpetrated by states. Comprehensive trade sanctions were a popular instrument of economic coercion throughout the 20th century, in part because they are less costly, less risky, and more palatable than military action. Targeted sanctions differ from comprehensive ones in coercive logic, the intended target, and the ultimate goal. Though similarly aimed at eliciting a change in state behavior, they focus on specific individuals and entities rather than the population at large. As Zachary Goldman and Damon McCoy have pointed out, “different kinds of malicious cyber activity demand different, tailored, deterrence strategies. This is because each category of cyber threat has a different motivation, and therefore will be sensitive to a different type of cost.”51 Nation-state hackers with political goals are unlikely to suffer the same consequences of a sanctions designation that independent cybercriminals with financial motivations will suffer. Similarly, designating a government official orchestrating an attack is unlikely to have the same impact as designating an individual two or three steps removed that launders money on behalf of a hacking group.\nTwo things complicate the effort to neatly distinguish between categories like cybercrime and nation-state activity and state and non-state actors. First, the convergence of financially-motivated cybercrime and nation-state activity makes it difficult to separate cyberattacks conducted for purely economic gain and those undertaken for political purposes.52 North Korean efforts to raise funds for its weapons of mass destruction program through cyber theft and ransom operations against financial institutions and cryptocurrency exchanges have demonstrated the difficulty of separating financial motivations from political goals.53 Similarly, state-sponsored economic espionage emanating from China blurs the distinction between financial and political aims as the theft of intellectual property aims to “support its strategic development goals—science and technology advancement, military modernization, and economic policy objectives.”54\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nSecond, the use of proxies for conducting offensive cyber operations often precludes a neat division between state and non-state actors in cyberspace. Tim Maurer’s comprehensive overview of the use of proxies for accomplishing offensive cyber operations details the spectrum of relationships between states and their proxies. These relationships range from overt delegation of activity to loose orchestration to passive enablement of proxy behavior. In the latter cases, those operating at a state’s behest may also have a foot in the criminal world. For example, in 2019, Treasury alleged that a Russian cybercriminal indicted and sanctioned for developing and distributing malware also operated on behalf of the Russian government, “highlighting the Russian government’s enlistment of cybercriminals for its own malicious purposes.”\n## Evaluating effectiveness\nIt is not within the remit of external observers to assess whether cyber sanctions effectively achieve deterrence. Much of the information needed to make such an assessment is classified or privately owned intelligence. Though Treasury publicly reports the value of transactions blocked under specific sanctions programs, others have pointed out that evaluating the success of cyber sanctions based on the financial value of prevented transactions is misleading. Therefore, it is difficult for policymakers to attribute any observed decrease in malicious cyber activity or change in activity to sanctions or determine whether activity levels would be even greater absent the threat of sanctions or imposition.\nWithin the U.S. government, Treasury’s Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) and the State Department’s Bureau of Intelligence and Research perform impact assessments. According to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), which published a review of U.S. sanctions programs and their effectiveness in 2019, “These assessments analyze the impacts of specific sanctions on a particular aspect of the sanction’s target—for example, the sanctions’ impact on the target country’s economy or trade.” OIA, for example, conducts impact assessments before a sanctions designation and after its imposition and may include factors like the target’s U.S.-\n Maurer, *Cyber Mercenaries*, 42-49.\n “Treasury Sanctions Evil Corp, the Russia-Based Cybercriminal Group Behind Dridex Malware,” U.S. Department of the Treasury, December 5, 2019, https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm845,\n Annie Fixler and Eric Lorber, “Counting Pennies Underestimates the Value of Treasury’s Cyber Sanctions,” Foundation for Defense of Democracies, November 4, 2019, https://www.fdd.org/analysis/2019/11/04/counting-pennies-underestimates-the-value-of-treasurys-cyber-sanctions/.\n Kimberly Gianopoulos, “Economic Sanctions: Agencies Assess Impacts on Targets, and Studies Suggest Several Factors Contribute to Sanctions’ Effectiveness,” U.S. Government Accountability Office, October 2019, 12, https://www.gao.gov/assets/710/701891.pdf.\n Ibid.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nbased assets, global holdings, and interactions with the United States and the potential cascading consequences of a sanctions designation.\nHowever, the report acknowledges that “these assessments do not analyze sanctions’ overall effectiveness in achieving broader U.S. policy goals or objectives, such as whether the sanctions are advancing the national security and policy priorities of the United States” (emphasis added). OIA distinguishes between impact and effect in its assessments:\nAccording to OIA officials, assessing impact is analyzing the potential or observed effect of the sanction on the target. According to officials, impact can be focused on a singular target or could be broader, such as the impact on the target country’s economy or trade flows. GAO’s report highlights that policymakers have difficulty isolating sanctions’ effects from those of other policy tools, dealing with shifting policy objectives, and identifying useful data for conducting assessments.\nThe threat of sanctions raises an additional challenge for evaluating effectiveness. Perhaps the most damning factor concerning the inconclusiveness of the academic literature is that even amongst academics “what counts as ‘effective’ (or ‘successful’) itself has been a contentious issue.”^[81]^\n## Factors for consideration\nStill, in trying to assess the effectiveness of cyber sanctions, policymakers should look at three key factors:\n(1) A target’s vulnerability to economic pressure,\n(2) The motivations underpinning offensive activity, and\n(3) How chosen targets support malicious activity.\n## Vulnerability to economic pressure\nDespite the lack of consensus regarding sanctions’ aims, those who have surveyed the academic literature note that a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure is critical for sanctions’ effectiveness. As one group of researchers put it, “the data suggest that the types of financial sanctions that have been deployed against states in the last two decades should have a greater\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nimpact on the decisionmaking [sic] of states for which attractiveness to international trade and investment is strategically significant.” In the cyber domain, this means that policymakers should pay attention to specific nation-state cyber threats that may be vulnerable to economic pressure. A sanction against an Iranian or North Korean government entity, for example, is unlikely to disrupt capabilities in the same way that a designation of a Russian entity might. U.S. sanctions have isolated Iran and North Korea from the global financial system, so additional targeted sanctions may be unlikely to significantly affect the ability to carry out future attacks or enjoy their proceeds. Indeed, these two actors have made the financial system the target of cyberattacks. However, actors elsewhere may be more exposed to the influence of the U.S. dollar or the euro in global financial markets and, therefore, more likely to pay attention to the punitive consequences of a sanction or have their capabilities disrupted as a result. For example, Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska, alleged that his net worth dropped by 80 percent—over $7 billion—as a result of U.S. sanctions related to “a range of malign activity around the globe,” including malicious cyber activity, imposed in 2018.\n## Actors’ motivations\nThe motives underpinning malicious cyber activity also affect an actor's vulnerability to sanctions. As mentioned above, Goldman and McCoy have argued that sanctions are an appropriate policy tool for dealing with financially motivated cyber threats—like cyber-enabled economic espionage—because they undermine the goal of the activity: profit. Still, the profit motive may make these actors more sensitive to sanctions than a politically motivated actor would be. Russian actors engaged in hack and leak operations or attacks on international organizations are not as likely to be dissuaded from engaging in their activity because sanctions have made it unprofitable if profitability was not necessarily a preeminent goal.\n## Means of supporting wrongful activity\nThe specific choice of target and whose behavioral change is the goal of sanctions are also likely to bear on how policymakers should evaluate effectiveness. Once policymakers have identified malicious activity, they can choose to go after several different targets, including the state actors that directed, orchestrated, or enabled the attack; the individuals directly engaged in the attack; or those that provide material, financial, or technological support for the attack. Again, these actors are not equally vulnerable to the effects of sanctions. Government officials that enjoy the backing and protection of the state may be less likely to be deterred than those whose legitimate commercial interests are at stake by aiding targets in circumventing sanctions. As one group of researchers at the Center for a New American Security put it, “To the extent that sanctions on non-state actors are focused on coercing a change in behavior, that strategy may have the greatest impact on the ecosystem of actual and would-be supporters of those groups, rather than on the groups themselves.” Simultaneously, sanctions can go after a specific target to change a third party’s behavior—returning to the Deripaska example described above, sanctioning Russian oligarchs was partly meant to signal to the Russian state that its conduct was unacceptable and leverage elite pain for behavioral change.\n## Effectiveness as opposed to what?\nEvaluating the impacts of sanctions cannot ignore the alternative instruments available to states\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n John Carlin, “Detect, Disrupt, Deter: A Whole-of-Government Approach to National Security Cyber Threats,” *Harvard National Security Journal* 7, (2016): 420, https://harvardnsj.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/13/2016/06/Carlin-FINAL.pdf.\n The impact of sanctions on an adversary’s risk calculus could potentially backfire if financially motivated actors are deterred from engaging in the lowest levels of criminal activity, which may generate profits incommensurate with the absorbed risk, but continue to engage in highly profitable but extremely destabilizing attacks.\n Rosenberg, et al., “The New Tools of Economic Warfare,” 28.\n “Treasury Designates Russian Oligarchs, Officials, and Entities in Response to Worldwide Malign Activity,” U.S. Department of the Treasury.\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nseeking to respond to wrongful behavior in cyberspace. This paper situates sanctions within the DIME(LE) framework to highlight the point that policymakers face the choice not of sanctioning or doing nothing but of sanctioning or releasing a diplomatic statement or responding with a retaliatory cyberattack or of doing nothing or of doing several of these. In the U.S. context, in particular, policymakers have adopted a “whole-of-government” approach to countering malicious cyber activity—in essence, one that involves all of the tools of statecraft outlined in the DIME(LE)., As a result, sanctions have frequently followed criminal charges against malicious cyber actors. In the U.S. context, the NSC-led interagency process provides a forum for discussing the effectiveness of sanctions relative to other policy instruments. But as with academic literature on the efficacy of sanctions on non-state actors, Dursun Peksen argues that scholarly work on the utility of sanctions relative to other policy instruments is similarly lacking.\nNonetheless, as policymakers impose sanctions, they must consider the potential escalatory consequences and how alternative policy instruments might compare. Rosenberg and Tama highlight the need to better assess where sanctions sit on the escalation ladder to strengthen their signaling value and ensure that efforts at cross-domain deterrence do not inadvertently compromise broader foreign policy objectives. As they put it, “if it is unclear whether an airstrike against a military facility is higher or lower on the escalation ladder than financial sanctions targeting a country’s most important economic sector, the target government may not understand the likely consequences of continuing to flout an international norm or U.S. demands.”\nCompared to actions like diplomatic statements, sanctions may be perceived as more escalatory since they aim to impose real financial costs and disrupt an operations’ financing. But in comparison to retaliatory cyberattacks or other military action, they may be less escalatory because their contours are narrowly defined, and policymakers can couple sanctions with clear statements of intention. The EU’s sanctions, which refrain from attributing responsibility for an attack to a specific state, may be less escalatory than those imposed by the United States, which, as described above, can and sometimes do allege state responsibility for wrongful behavior.\nIf adversaries see sanctions as escalatory, they may retaliate. Sanctions have generated such retaliation: Iran retaliated for U.S. sanctions with cyberattacks against the financial system. The potential backlash to Washington’s gung-ho attitude toward financial sanctions may occur on a longer time horizon but carries arguably more significant consequence for U.S. global power.\nThe potential consequences mean that policymakers evaluating the effectiveness of cyber sanctions at deterring wrongful behavior must also consider the long-term trajectory of the tool’s use and how decisions within the broader foreign policy context affect the reception of sanctions.\n## Moving beyond deterrence\nA general emphasis on deterrence obscures the variety of different functions that sanctions can perform and the diversity of motives underpinning malicious cyber activity. Few, if any, policymakers would argue that the outright cessation of malicious cyber activity is a realistic goal that could be achieved by targeted financial sanctions. Given that some, like North Korea, pursue cybercrime as a means of sanctions evasion, one might even argue that sanctions are counterproductive if the goal is understood to stop malicious cyber activity.^[130]^ As described above, the academic and policy literature on the effectiveness of cyber sanctions at deterrence is difficult to measure. So why do policymakers continue to employ sanctions in the seeming absence of compelling evidence about their effectiveness?\nThe academic literature on targeted sanctions has attempted to account for some of the different aims of sanctions and the diverse threats they can target by introducing three potential purposes—constraint, coercion, and signaling.^[131]^ Even these, however, ignore the nuanced and specific purposes for imposing sanctions in response to malicious cyber activity. To say that a sanctions designation aims to “signal,” for example, ignores important features of the message itself, its intended audience, and its contribution to the broader goal of sending a message by sanctioning.\nOthers divide the purposes of sanctions into “symbolic” or “expressive” and “instrumental” ones.^[132]^ Symbolic or expressive purposes relate to the political interests served by doing something in response to wrongful behavior—i.e., signaling. The repeated imposition of sanctions may introduce sustained friction in the relationship between the proxy and the state that changes the state’s overall calculus about how and when to engage in malicious cyber activity. Over time, this may lead to a change in the nature of the state’s relationship with its proxies and the degree of risk it is willing to accept when engaging in offensive cyber operations. However, it would be misleading to not include these, and they represent an interesting examples of instances in which sanctioners can target key economic elites in order to elicit a change in state behavior.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\n|  10/22/2020 | EU | 13694), Ukraine (E.O. 13661)\nCouncil Regulation (EU) 2019/796 | 2 individuals, 1 entity | Russia | No  |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\n|  10/22/2020 | U.S. | Election interference (E.O. 13848) | 5 entities | Iran | No  |\n|  10/23/2020 | U.S. | CAATSA | 1 entity | Russia | No  |\n## Do cyber sanctions deter?\nAs described above, policymakers in both the United States and European Union emphasize that cyber sanctions aim to deter malicious actors and behavior. As Zachary Goldman and Damon McCoy have pointed out, “different kinds of malicious cyber activity demand different, tailored, deterrence strategies. This is because each category of cyber threat has a different motivation, and therefore will be sensitive to a different type of cost.”51 Nation-state hackers with political goals are unlikely to suffer the same consequences of a sanctions designation that independent cybercriminals with financial motivations will suffer. Similarly, designating a government official orchestrating an attack is unlikely to have the same impact as designating an individual two or three steps removed that launders money on behalf of a hacking group.\nTwo things complicate the effort to neatly distinguish between categories like cybercrime and nation-state activity and state and non-state actors. First, the convergence of financially-motivated cybercrime and nation-state activity makes it difficult to separate cyberattacks conducted for purely economic gain and those undertaken for political purposes.52 North Korean efforts to raise funds for its weapons of mass destruction program through cyber theft and ransom operations against financial institutions and cryptocurrency exchanges have demonstrated the difficulty of separating financial motivations from political goals.53 Similarly, state-sponsored economic espionage emanating from China blurs the distinction between financial and political aims as the theft of intellectual property aims to “support its strategic development goals—science and technology advancement, military modernization, and economic policy objectives.”54\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nSecond, the use of proxies for conducting offensive cyber operations often precludes a neat division between state and non-state actors in cyberspace. Tim Maurer’s comprehensive overview of the use of proxies for accomplishing offensive cyber operations details the spectrum of relationships between states and their proxies.⁵⁵ These relationships range from overt delegation of activity to loose orchestration to passive enablement of proxy behavior. In the latter cases, those operating at a state’s behest may also have a foot in the criminal world. For example, in 2019, Treasury alleged that a Russian cybercriminal indicted and sanctioned for developing and distributing malware also operated on behalf of the Russian government, “highlighting the Russian government’s enlistment of cybercriminals for its own malicious purposes.”⁵⁶\n## Evaluating effectiveness\nIt is not within the remit of external observers to assess whether cyber sanctions effectively achieve deterrence. Much of the information needed to make such an assessment is classified or privately owned intelligence. Though Treasury publicly reports the value of transactions blocked under specific sanctions programs, others have pointed out that evaluating the success of cyber sanctions based on the financial value of prevented transactions is misleading.⁵⁷ Therefore, it is difficult for policymakers to attribute any observed decrease in malicious cyber activity or change in activity to sanctions or determine whether activity levels would be even greater absent the threat of sanctions or imposition.\nWithin the U.S. government, Treasury’s Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) and the State Department’s Bureau of Intelligence and Research perform impact assessments.⁵⁸ According to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), which published a review of U.S. sanctions programs and their effectiveness in 2019, “These assessments analyze the impacts of specific sanctions on a particular aspect of the sanction’s target—for example, the sanctions’ impact on the target country’s economy Perhaps the most damning factor concerning the inconclusiveness of the academic literature is that even amongst academics “what counts as ‘effective’ (or ‘successful’) itself has been a contentious issue.”^^\n## Factors for consideration\nStill, in trying to assess the effectiveness of cyber sanctions, policymakers should look at three key factors:\n(1) A target’s vulnerability to economic pressure,\n(2) The motivations underpinning offensive activity, and\n(3) How chosen targets support malicious activity.\n## Vulnerability to economic pressure\nDespite the lack of consensus regarding sanctions’ aims, those who have surveyed the academic literature note that a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure is critical for sanctions’ effectiveness. As one group of researchers put it, “the data suggest that the types of financial sanctions that have been deployed against states in the last two decades should have a greater\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nimpact on the decisionmaking [sic] of states for which attractiveness to international trade and investment is strategically significant.”⁸² In the cyber domain, this means that policymakers should pay attention to specific nation-state cyber threats that may be vulnerable to economic pressure. A sanction against an Iranian or North Korean government entity, for example, is unlikely to disrupt capabilities in the same way that a designation of a Russian entity might. U.S. sanctions have isolated Iran and North Korea from the global financial system,⁸³ so additional targeted sanctions may be unlikely to significantly affect the ability to carry out future attacks or enjoy their proceeds. Indeed, these two actors have made the financial system the target of cyberattacks.⁸⁴ However, actors elsewhere may be more exposed to the influence of the U.S. dollar or the euro in global financial markets and, therefore, more likely to pay attention to the punitive consequences of a sanction or have their capabilities disrupted as a result. For example, Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska, alleged that his net worth dropped by 80 percent—over $7 billion—as a result of U.S. sanctions related to “a range of malign activity around the globe,” including malicious cyber activity, imposed in 2018.⁸⁵\n## Actors’ motivations\nThe motives underpinning malicious cyber activity also affect an actor's vulnerability to sanctions. Once policymakers have identified malicious activity, they can choose to go after several different targets, including the state actors that directed, orchestrated, or enabled the attack; the individuals directly engaged in the attack; or those that provide material, financial, or technological support for the attack. Again, these actors are not equally vulnerable to the effects of sanctions. Government officials that enjoy the backing and protection of the state may be less likely to be deterred than those whose legitimate commercial interests are at stake by aiding targets in circumventing sanctions. In the U.S. context, the NSC-led interagency process provides a forum for discussing the effectiveness of sanctions relative to other policy instruments.¹⁰² But as with academic literature on the efficacy of sanctions on non-state actors, Dursun Peksen argues that scholarly work on the utility of sanctions relative to other policy instruments is similarly lacking.¹⁰³\nNonetheless, as policymakers impose sanctions, they must consider the potential escalatory consequences and how alternative policy instruments might compare. Rosenberg and Tama highlight the need to better assess where sanctions sit on the escalation ladder to strengthen their signaling value and ensure that efforts at cross-domain deterrence do not inadvertently compromise broader foreign policy objectives.¹⁰⁴ As they put it, “if it is unclear whether an airstrike against a military facility is higher or lower on the escalation ladder than financial sanctions targeting a country’s most important economic sector, the target government may not understand the likely consequences of continuing to flout an international norm or U.S. demands.”¹⁰⁵\nCompared to actions like diplomatic statements, sanctions may be perceived as more escalatory since they aim to impose real financial costs and disrupt an operations’ financing. But in comparison to retaliatory cyberattacks or other military action, they may be less escalatory because their contours are narrowly defined, and policymakers can couple sanctions with clear statements of intention.¹⁰⁶ The EU’s sanctions, which refrain from attributing responsibility for an attack to a specific state, may be less escalatory than those imposed by the United States,¹⁰⁷ which, as described above, can and sometimes do allege state responsibility for wrongful behavior.\nIf adversaries see sanctions as escalatory, they may retaliate. The potential backlash to Washington’s gung-ho attitude toward financial sanctions may occur on a longer time horizon but carries arguably more significant consequence for U.S. global power.\nThe potential consequences mean that policymakers evaluating the effectiveness of cyber sanctions at deterring wrongful behavior must also consider the long-term trajectory of the tool’s use and how decisions within the broader foreign policy context affect the reception of sanctions.\n## Moving beyond deterrence\nA general emphasis on deterrence obscures the variety of different functions that sanctions can perform and the diversity of motives underpinning malicious cyber activity. Few, if any, policymakers would argue that the outright cessation of malicious cyber activity is a realistic goal that could be achieved by targeted financial sanctions. Given that some, like North Korea, pursue cybercrime as a means of sanctions evasion, one might even argue that sanctions are counterproductive if the goal is understood to stop malicious cyber activity.^^ As described above, the academic and policy literature on the effectiveness of cyber sanctions at deterrence is difficult to measure. So why do policymakers continue to employ sanctions in the seeming absence of compelling evidence about their effectiveness?\nThe academic literature on targeted sanctions has attempted to account for some of the different aims of sanctions and the diverse threats they can target by introducing three potential purposes—constraint, coercion, and signaling.^^ Even these, however, ignore the nuanced and specific purposes for imposing sanctions in response to malicious cyber activity. To say that a sanctions designation aims to “signal,” for example, ignores important features of the message itself, its intended audience, and its contribution to the broader goal of sending a message by sanctioning.\nOthers divide the purposes of sanctions into “symbolic” or “expressive” and “instrumental” ones.^^ Symbolic or expressive purposes relate to the political interests served by doing something in response to wrongful behavior—i.e., signaling. Instrumental objectives relate to desired policy or behavior changes—i.e., coercion and constraint.\n^^ Elizabeth Rosenberg and Neil Bhatiya, “Busting North Korea’s Sanctions Evasion,” Center for a New American Security, March 4, 2020, https://www.cnas.org/publications/commentary/busting-north-koreas-sanctions-evasion.\n^^ Giumelli, *How EU sanctions work*, 18-19.\n^^ Taehee Whang, “Playing to the Home Crowd? Symbolic Use of Economic Sanctions in the United States,” *International Studies Quarterly* 55, no. 3 (September 2011): 787-788, https://www.jstor.org/stable/23020066.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nBuilding on the scholarship of Garrett Hinck and Tim Maurer, which examined the role that criminal charges play in countering malicious cyber activity,¹³³ cyber sanctions can be categorized to serve the following symbolic purposes: 1) attribution, 2) information-sharing, 3) audience satisfaction, 4) cooperation with allies, and 5) norm development and instrumental ones: 6) punishment of malicious actors and 7) disruption of capabilities, which cumulatively aspire to 8) deterrence.\n## Attribution\nIn the context of malicious cyber activity, “attribution” has multiple dimensions—it can relate to the machine used in an attack, the individual that perpetrated the attack, or the “ultimately responsible party” for the attack.¹³⁴ Ascertaining responsibility is a complicated matter. The degree to which a state might be responsible for malicious activity varies from an inability to prevent malicious attacks to active participation in an attack.¹³⁵\nSanctions designations are public listings that name individuals or entities in response to malicious behavior. As Kristen Eichensehr has argued, they can attribute wrongful conduct by naming the individual or entity that directly perpetrated a cyberattack or indicating state responsibility for an attack.¹³⁶\nThis is not always the case. Because targets can be sanctioned for materially, financially, or technologically enabling a previously designated actor, they do not always publicize attribution in the sense of identifying hackers. And because ascertaining the nature of the relationship between a state and a hacker can be difficult, not all sanctions allege that a state enabled or orchestrated wrongful behavior in cyberspace.\nBut in some cases, sanctions do serve to implicate a state in malicious cyber activity. Questions for evaluating effectiveness\n|  Function | Questions  |\n| --- | --- |\n|  Attribution | • Do the statements accompanying a sanctions designation claim that the named entities perpetrated a cyberattack itself?\n• Do the statements accompanying a sanctions designation allege state responsibility for wrongful behavior in cyberspace?\n• Have other policies or legal action (i.e., indictments) made similar attribution claims?  |\n|  Audience satisfaction | • Do actors in the private sector or civil society find sanctions a meaningful and appropriate response to malicious activity?\n• Do allies release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action?  |\n|  Cooperation with allies | • Do (or could) other jurisdictions impose sanctions against the same targets?\n• Do other countries release diplomatic statements affirming the appropriateness of the action? What is the likelihood of the target engaging in retaliation, and what would the consequences of retaliation be?\n- Are the costs absorbed by the sender of sanctions proportionate to the costs imposed on targets?\n- What alternative policy options are available, and how do the effects of these tools compare to those of sanctions?\n- What might the long-term consequences be for the architecture of the global financial system?\nHaving discussed the eight purposes sanctions may seek to serve, the operational question remains whether policymakers clearly articulate these objectives and how they measure sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving any of these goals. The aim of preventing low-level cybercrime like business email compromise scams is different from seeking to encourage states to rein in their proxies when conducting offensive cyber operations.\nNo matter which goals policymakers have in mind with a sanctions designation, they should keep in mind the considerations outlined above pertaining to alternative policy instruments and long-term consequences. Future research in this area should address how policy should deal with the distinction between “cyber” as a threat itself and as a means for accomplishing other ends like intelligence collection, economic competition, or control over domestic political spaces. The United States’ use, in particular, of a variety of different legal instruments—not just the cyber-specific sanctions framework—highlights the fact that cybercrime and national security threats require a variety of flexible tools. Part outlines the definitional issues related to the scope of “malicious cyber activity” and what, therefore, constitutes a “cyber sanction.” It then provides an overview of the designations to date in the United States and Europe. Part two discusses how policymakers and academics evaluate sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving often-touted deterrence goals and specific considerations related to policy alternatives and long-term consequences. Policymakers cannot ignore the alternative instruments available to respond to malicious cyber activity in thinking about effectiveness and must weigh the trade-offs associated with alternative responses to cyberattacks. Finally, policymakers cannot ignore how firms and other states respond to and perceive the credibility of U.S. sanctions in the long-run—both as it relates to their imposition and removal (or lack thereof). They must consider the corresponding implications for the architecture of the global financial system and United States’ ability to weaponize its financial position. Part three then offers a categorization of the different purposes that sanctions can serve beyond deterrence. These purposes include attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, punishment, and disruption of capabilities—all of which contribute cumulatively to the overarching goal of deterrence.\n## Defining “cyber sanctions”\n### What do sanctions entail?\nThe United States and EU’s cyber sanctions are targeted sanctions that differ from sanctions imposed during and before the 1990s. Comprehensive trade sanctions were a popular instrument of economic coercion throughout the 20th century, in part because they are less costly, less risky, and more palatable than military action. Targeted sanctions differ from comprehensive ones in coercive logic, the intended target, and the ultimate goal. Though similarly aimed at eliciting a change in state behavior, they focus on specific individuals and entities rather than the population at large.¹⁶ They assume that singling out individuals or groups will better “raise the target regime’s costs of noncompliance.”¹⁷ Targeted sanctions can also aim to change the\n¹⁶ Arne Tostensen and Beate Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” World Politics 53, no. 3 : 380, 382.\n¹⁷ Daniel Drezner, “How Smart Are Smart Sanctions?” International Studies Review 5, no. 1 : 107; see also Tostensen and Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” 380, 386; Thomas G. Targeted sanctions are understood to have additional value for constraining and signaling. By “constraining,” these scholars refer to complicating an actor’s ability to engage in internationally wrongful behavior.²⁰ By “signaling,” they refer to sending a message to the target, domestic audiences, and international audiences that expresses support for norms of appropriate behavior.²¹\nOne type of targeted sanction, restrictive financial measures (also referred to as targeted financial sanctions), is increasingly the tool of choice for policymakers seeking to impose consequences for internationally wrongful behavior. As Zachary Goldman and Damon McCoy have pointed out, “different kinds of malicious cyber activity demand different, tailored, deterrence strategies. This is because each category of cyber threat has a different motivation, and therefore will be sensitive to a different type of cost.”51 Nation-state hackers with political goals are unlikely to suffer the same consequences of a sanctions designation that independent cybercriminals with financial motivations will suffer. Similarly, designating a government official orchestrating an attack is unlikely to have the same impact as designating an individual two or three steps removed that launders money on behalf of a hacking group.\nTwo things complicate the effort to neatly distinguish between categories like cybercrime and nation-state activity and state and non-state actors. First, the convergence of financially-motivated cybercrime and nation-state activity makes it difficult to separate cyberattacks conducted for purely economic gain and those undertaken for political purposes.52 North Korean efforts to raise funds for its weapons of mass destruction program through cyber theft and ransom operations against financial institutions and cryptocurrency exchanges have demonstrated the difficulty of separating financial motivations from political goals.53 Similarly, state-sponsored economic espionage emanating from China blurs the distinction between financial and political aims as the theft of intellectual property aims to “support its strategic development goals—science and technology advancement, military modernization, and economic policy objectives.”54\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nSecond, the use of proxies for conducting offensive cyber operations often precludes a neat division between state and non-state actors in cyberspace. Tim Maurer’s comprehensive overview of the use of proxies for accomplishing offensive cyber operations details the spectrum of relationships between states and their proxies.⁵⁵ These relationships range from overt delegation of activity to loose orchestration to passive enablement of proxy behavior. In the latter cases, those operating at a state’s behest may also have a foot in the criminal world. For example, in 2019, Treasury alleged that a Russian cybercriminal indicted and sanctioned for developing and distributing malware also operated on behalf of the Russian government, “highlighting the Russian government’s enlistment of cybercriminals for its own malicious purposes.”⁵⁶\n## Evaluating effectiveness\nIt is not within the remit of external observers to assess whether cyber sanctions effectively achieve deterrence. Much of the information needed to make such an assessment is classified or privately owned intelligence. Though Treasury publicly reports the value of transactions blocked under specific sanctions programs, others have pointed out that evaluating the success of cyber sanctions based on the financial value of prevented transactions is misleading.⁵⁷ Therefore, it is difficult for policymakers to attribute any observed decrease in malicious cyber activity or change in activity to sanctions or determine whether activity levels would be even greater absent the threat of sanctions or imposition.\nWithin the U.S. government, Treasury’s Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) and the State Perhaps the most damning factor concerning the inconclusiveness of the academic literature is that even amongst academics “what counts as ‘effective’ (or ‘successful’) itself has been a contentious issue.”^[81]^\n## Factors for consideration\nStill, in trying to assess the effectiveness of cyber sanctions, policymakers should look at three key factors:\n(1) A target’s vulnerability to economic pressure,\n(2) The motivations underpinning offensive activity, and\n(3) How chosen targets support malicious activity.\n## Vulnerability to economic pressure\nDespite the lack of consensus regarding sanctions’ aims, those who have surveyed the academic literature note that a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure is critical for sanctions’ effectiveness. As one group of researchers put it, “the data suggest that the types of financial sanctions that have been deployed against states in the last two decades should have a greater\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\nimpact on the decisionmaking [sic] of states for which attractiveness to international trade and investment is strategically significant.”⁸² In the cyber domain, this means that policymakers should pay attention to specific nation-state cyber threats that may be vulnerable to economic pressure. A sanction against an Iranian or North Korean government entity, for example, is unlikely to disrupt capabilities in the same way that a designation of a Russian entity might. U.S. sanctions have isolated Iran and North Korea from the global financial system,⁸³ so additional targeted sanctions may be unlikely to significantly affect the ability to carry out future attacks or enjoy their proceeds. Indeed, these two actors have made the financial system the target of cyberattacks.⁸⁴ However, actors elsewhere may be more exposed to the influence of the U.S. dollar or the euro in global financial markets and, therefore, more likely to pay attention to the punitive consequences of a sanction or have their capabilities disrupted as a result. For example, Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska, alleged that his net worth dropped by 80 percent—over $7 billion—as a result of U.S. sanctions related to “a range of malign activity around the globe,” including malicious cyber activity, imposed in 2018.⁸⁵\n## Actors’ motivations\nThe motives underpinning malicious cyber activity also affect an actor's vulnerability to sanctions. Still, the profit motive may make these actors more sensitive to sanctions than a politically motivated actor would be.⁸⁸ Russian actors engaged in hack and leak operations or attacks on international organizations are not as likely to be dissuaded from engaging in their activity because sanctions have made it unprofitable if profitability was not necessarily a preeminent goal.\n## Means of supporting wrongful activity\nThe specific choice of target and whose behavioral change is the goal of sanctions are also likely to bear on how policymakers should evaluate effectiveness. Once policymakers have identified malicious activity, they can choose to go after several different targets, including the state actors that directed, orchestrated, or enabled the attack; the individuals directly engaged in the attack; or those that provide material, financial, or technological support for the attack. Again, these actors are not equally vulnerable to the effects of sanctions. Government officials that enjoy the backing and protection of the state may be less likely to be deterred than those whose legitimate commercial interests are at stake by aiding targets in circumventing sanctions. As one group of researchers at the Center for a New American Security put it, “To the extent that sanctions on non-state actors are focused on coercing a change in behavior, that strategy may have the greatest impact on the ecosystem of actual and would-be supporters of those groups, rather than on the groups themselves.”⁸⁹ Simultaneously, sanctions can go after a specific target to change a third party’s behavior—returning to the Deripaska example described above, sanctioning Russian oligarchs was partly meant to signal to the Russian state that its conduct was unacceptable and leverage elite In the U.S. context, the NSC-led interagency process provides a forum for discussing the effectiveness of sanctions relative to other policy instruments.¹⁰² But as with academic literature on the efficacy of sanctions on non-state actors, Dursun Peksen argues that scholarly work on the utility of sanctions relative to other policy instruments is similarly lacking.¹⁰³\nNonetheless, as policymakers impose sanctions, they must consider the potential escalatory consequences and how alternative policy instruments might compare. Rosenberg and Tama highlight the need to better assess where sanctions sit on the escalation ladder to strengthen their signaling value and ensure that efforts at cross-domain deterrence do not inadvertently compromise broader foreign policy objectives.¹⁰⁴ As they put it, “if it is unclear whether an airstrike against a military facility is higher or lower on the escalation ladder than financial sanctions targeting a country’s most important economic sector, the target government may not understand the likely consequences of continuing to flout an international norm or U.S. demands.”¹⁰⁵\nCompared to actions like diplomatic statements, sanctions may be perceived as more escalatory since they aim to impose real financial costs and disrupt an operations’ financing. But in comparison to retaliatory cyberattacks or other military action, they may be less escalatory because their contours are narrowly defined, and policymakers can couple sanctions with clear statements of intention.¹⁰⁶ The EU’s sanctions, which refrain from attributing responsibility for an attack to a specific state, may be less escalatory than those imposed by the United States,¹⁰⁷ which, as described above, can and sometimes do allege state responsibility for wrongful behavior.\nIf adversaries see sanctions as escalatory, they may retaliate. Sanctions have generated such retaliation: Iran retaliated for U.S. sanctions with cyberattacks against the financial system. As Peter Feaver and Eric Lorber have put it, targeted financial sanctions rely on calculations about business risk, and “If global business conditions change, the firms might re-calculate that engaging in financial transactions with those targeted states outweighs the costs.”¹¹⁰ This risk of such re-calculation may be heightened if sanctions create incentives for businesses to pursue transactions in other currencies or for countries to develop alternative financial architectures.¹¹¹\nThese concerns—and consideration of cyber sanctions generally—cannot be divorced from the broader context in which the United States has aggressively pursued the use of sanctions to achieve a range of foreign policy goals, sometimes to the detriment of ally relationships. Part outlines the definitional issues related to the scope of “malicious cyber activity” and what, therefore, constitutes a “cyber sanction.” It then provides an overview of the designations to date in the United States and Europe. Part two discusses how policymakers and academics evaluate sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving often-touted deterrence goals and specific considerations related to policy alternatives and long-term consequences. Policymakers cannot ignore the alternative instruments available to respond to malicious cyber activity in thinking about effectiveness and must weigh the trade-offs associated with alternative responses to cyberattacks. Finally, policymakers cannot ignore how firms and other states respond to and perceive the credibility of U.S. sanctions in the long-run—both as it relates to their imposition and removal (or lack thereof). They must consider the corresponding implications for the architecture of the global financial system and United States’ ability to weaponize its financial position. Part three then offers a categorization of the different purposes that sanctions can serve beyond deterrence. These purposes include attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, punishment, and disruption of capabilities—all of which contribute cumulatively to the overarching goal of deterrence.\n\n---\n\n## # Conclusion\n\nThe definitional issues highlighted at the beginning of this paper related to what constitutes malicious cyber activity and should be included within this paper’s scope and the variety of aims of sanctions can raise a question about whether it makes sense to speak of a country or jurisdiction’s “cyber policy” or consider cyber issues a facet of a broader foreign policy. Future research in this area should address how policy should deal with the distinction between “cyber” as a threat itself and as a means for accomplishing other ends like intelligence collection, economic competition, or control over domestic political spaces. The United States’ use, in particular, of a variety of different legal instruments—not just the cyber-specific sanctions framework—highlights the fact that cybercrime and national security threats require a variety of flexible tools. More clearly delineating how and why cyber activity crosses a line of acceptability is crucial to promoting responsible behavior in cyberspace and identifying appropriate mechanisms for responding to harms.\nMore empirical research is also needed in this area. Much of the academic literature on sanctions focuses on those levied against states and deals insufficiently with the success of sanctions against nonstate and proxy actors. $^{166}$ As transnational threats multiply and policymakers reach for sanctions in response, they should have a clear evidence base supporting their decision making.\nThough policymakers often emphasize the goal of deterrence, articulation of the considerations for evaluating the effectiveness of sanctions is scant, even among government actors with access to the full array of intelligence necessary to make such evaluations. Policymakers should consider a target’s vulnerability to economic pressure, actors’ motivations, and the role that\n$^{166}$ Peksen, “When Do Imposed Economic Sanctions Work?,” 7-8.\n35\n[DRAFT – October 2020]\ntargets play in wrongful behavior in seeking to evaluate the likely outcomes of a sanctions designation and its effectiveness. Furthermore, questions of effectiveness also require attention to alternative policy options and long-term consequences.\nMoving beyond deterrence and cost imposition, the diversity of actors against which policymakers impose sanctions requires more nuanced thinking. In the absence of clear frameworks for evaluating effectiveness and relative pessimism about sanctions’ effectiveness, policymakers continue to reach for the tool. Therefore, our understanding of the purposes of sanctions should account for functions like attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, and punishment.\nDespite being hailed as ineffective by academic scholars, policymakers continue to employ sanctions. Data collected by the Center for a New American Security shows that the current U.S. administration is more than willing to sanction adversaries. Even though 2019 saw the fewest designations during the current administration, the yearly total was still more than those of any single year under the previous administration.¹⁶⁷ And the EU’s recent implementation of its cyber sanctions framework for the first time indicates that neither is the policy tool falling out of favor abroad.\n¹⁶⁷ Johnpatrick Imperiale, “Sanctions by the Numbers,” Center for a New American Security, February 27, 2020, https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/sanctions-by-the-numbers.\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",

    "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\n# Countering Malicious Cyber Activity: Targeted Financial Sanctions\n\nNatalie Thompson*\n\nSince 2012 policymakers in the United States and Europe have imposed targeted financial sanctions against malicious cyber operators with the stated goal of deterring such activity. This draft paper provides an overview of the legal frameworks for sanctioning malicious cyber actors and the set of relevant sanctions imposed to date. Despite an emphasis on the goal of deterrence, both policymakers and academics have difficulty determining whether sanctions deter malicious cyber activity. Considering the continued use of cyber sanctions, this paper highlights key considerations for policymakers to evaluate whether sanctions can deter wrongful behavior in cyberspace.\n\nKeywords: sanctions, economic statecraft, cyber, deterrence, descriptive studies, policy evaluation\n\n*Research Assistant, Cyber Policy Initiative, Technology and International Affairs Program, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Washington, DC, USA\n\nContact: thompsonr.natalie@gmail.com\n\nSpecial thanks go to my colleagues—especially Tim Maurer, George Perkovich, Jon Bateman, Ariel Levite, and Arthur Nelson—for supporting this research. Thanks also to Michael Daniel, Martha Finnemore, Duncan Hollis, Eric Lorber, Teddy Nemeroff, Patryk Pawlak, Allison Peters, Sverrir Steinsson, Juan Zarate, and a former U.S. Department of State official for their detailed feedback on the draft. Finally, thanks to the team at EU Cyber Direct for providing the opportunity to present an earlier draft of the paper at the 2020 Closing the Gap International Conference on Cyber, Digital, and Tech and to the conference participants for their thoughtful questions and comments. This draft reflects developments through October 2020 when it was finalized. All errors and omissions are the author's alone.\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",

Part two discusses how policymakers and academics evaluate sanctions’ effectiveness at achieving often-touted deterrence goals and specific considerations related to policy alternatives and long-term consequences. Policymakers cannot ignore the alternative instruments available to respond to malicious cyber activity in thinking about effectiveness and must weigh the trade-offs associated with alternative responses to cyberattacks. These purposes include attribution, information-sharing, audience satisfaction, cooperation with allies, norm development, punishment, and disruption of capabilities—all of which contribute cumulatively to the overarching goal of deterrence.\n\n## Defining “cyber sanctions”\n\n### What do sanctions entail?\n\nThe United States and EU’s cyber sanctions are targeted sanctions that differ from sanctions imposed during and before the 1990s. Comprehensive trade sanctions were a popular instrument of economic coercion throughout the 20th century, in part because they are less costly, less risky, and more palatable than military action. Targeted sanctions differ from comprehensive ones in coercive logic, the intended target, and the ultimate goal. Though similarly aimed at eliciting a change in state behavior, they focus on specific individuals and entities rather than the population at large.¹⁶ They assume that singling out individuals or groups will better “raise the target regime’s costs of noncompliance.”¹⁷ Targeted sanctions can also aim to change the\n\n¹⁶ Arne Tostensen and Beate Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” World Politics 53, no. 3 (April 2002): 380, 382.\n¹⁷ Daniel Drezner, “How Smart Are Smart Sanctions?” International Studies Review 5, no. 1 (March 2003): 107; see also Tostensen and Bull, “Are Smart Sanctions Feasible?” 380, 386; Thomas G. Weiss, “Sanctions as a Foreign Policy Tool: Weighing Humanitarian Impulses,” Journal of Peace Research 36, no. 5 (September 1999): 503; Daniel Drezner, “Sanctions Sometimes Smart: Targeted Sanctions in Theory and Practice,” International Studies Review 13, no. 1 (March 2011): 96, https://www.jstor.org/stable/23016144; and Daniel Drezner, “Targeted\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",
    "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\nbehavior of the targeted individuals or organizations themselves, making them useful tools for dealing with non-state actors and treating cases in which states employ proxies to accomplish their goals.¹⁸\n\nFurther, while comprehensive sanctions often aim to change policy or behavior — and sometimes, explicitly or implicitly, wholesale regime change¹⁹—scholars studying targeted sanctions recognize their utility for achieving more modest policy goals. Targeted sanctions are understood to have additional value for constraining and signaling. By “constraining,” these scholars refer to complicating an actor’s ability to engage in internationally wrongful behavior.²⁰ By “signaling,” they refer to sending a message to the target, domestic audiences, and international audiences that expresses support for norms of appropriate behavior.²¹\n\nOne type of targeted sanction, restrictive financial measures (also referred to as targeted financial sanctions), is increasingly the tool of choice for policymakers seeking to impose consequences for internationally wrongful behavior. Targeted financial sanctions include asset freezes, blocking transactions with designated individuals or entities, and denying access to capital markets.²² The tool relies on the preeminence of certain currencies and jurisdictions in global financial transactions.²³ Big financial players like the United States, Europe, and, to a lesser extent, China can weaponize the financial system to prevent specific individuals or organizations from transacting in their respective currencies.     "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\nsanctions.³⁰ And the United States has used its cyber-specific framework and a different election interference framework to punish Russian cyber-enabled influence operators.³¹\n\nThese Iran- and Russia-linked cases are somewhat ambiguous as to whether or not they constitute cyber-enabled harms that should be included in this paper. They do not fit neatly into the definition of cyberattack promulgated by the U.S. National Institute of Technology and Standards: “An attack, via cyberspace, targeting an enterprise’s use of cyberspace for the purpose of disrupting, disabling, destroying, or maliciously controlling a computing environment/infrastructure; or destroying the integrity of the data or stealing controlled information.”³² For example, monitoring dissidents or using social media to promote narratives online does not necessarily compromise data confidentiality, integrity, or availability. However, it would be misleading to not include these, and they represent an interesting examples of instances in which sanctioners can target key economic elites in order to elicit a change in state behavior.\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",
    "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\n|  10/22/2020 | EU | 13694), Ukraine (E.O. 13661)\nCouncil Regulation (EU) 2019/796 | 2 individuals, 1 entity | Russia | No  |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\n|  10/22/2020 | U.S. | Election interference (E.O. 13848) | 5 entities | Iran | No  |\n|  10/23/2020 | U.S. | CAATSA | 1 entity | Russia | No  |\n\n## Do cyber sanctions deter?\n\nAs described above, policymakers in both the United States and European Union emphasize that cyber sanctions aim to deter malicious actors and behavior. As Zachary Goldman and Damon McCoy have pointed out, “different kinds of malicious cyber activity demand different, tailored, deterrence strategies. This is because each category of cyber threat has a different motivation, and therefore will be sensitive to a different type of cost.”51 Nation-state hackers with political goals are unlikely to suffer the same consequences of a sanctions designation that independent cybercriminals with financial motivations will suffer. Similarly, designating a government official orchestrating an attack is unlikely to have the same impact as designating an individual two or three steps removed that launders money on behalf of a hacking group.\n\nTwo things complicate the effort to neatly distinguish between categories like cybercrime and nation-state activity and state and non-state actors. First, the convergence of financially-motivated cybercrime and nation-state activity makes it difficult to separate cyberattacks conducted for purely economic gain and those undertaken for political purposes.52 North Korean efforts to raise funds for its weapons of mass destruction program through cyber theft and ransom operations against financial institutions and cryptocurrency exchanges have demonstrated the difficulty of separating financial motivations from political goals.53 Similarly, state-sponsored economic espionage emanating from China blurs the distinction between financial and political aims as the theft of intellectual property aims to “support its strategic development goals—science and technology advancement, military modernization, and economic policy objectives.”54\n\nElectronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3770816",
    "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\nSecond, the use of proxies for conducting offensive cyber operations often precludes a neat division between state and non-state actors in cyberspace. Tim Maurer’s comprehensive overview of the use of proxies for accomplishing offensive cyber operations details the spectrum of relationships between states and their proxies.⁵⁵ These relationships range from overt delegation of activity to loose orchestration to passive enablement of proxy behavior. In the latter cases, those operating at a state’s behest may also have a foot in the criminal world. For example, in 2019, Treasury alleged that a Russian cybercriminal indicted and sanctioned for developing and distributing malware also operated on behalf of the Russian government, “highlighting the Russian government’s enlistment of cybercriminals for its own malicious purposes.”⁵⁶\n\n## Evaluating effectiveness\n\nIt is not within the remit of external observers to assess whether cyber sanctions effectively achieve deterrence. Much of the information needed to make such an assessment is classified or privately owned intelligence. Though Treasury publicly reports the value of transactions blocked under specific sanctions programs, others have pointed out that evaluating the success of cyber sanctions based on the financial value of prevented transactions is misleading.⁵⁷ Therefore, it is difficult for policymakers to attribute any observed decrease in malicious cyber activity or change in activity to sanctions or determine whether activity levels would be even greater absent the threat of sanctions or imposition.\n\nWithin the U.S. government, Treasury’s Office of Intelligence and Analysis (OIA) and the State Department’s Bureau of Intelligence and Research perform impact assessments.⁵⁸ According to the Government Accountability Office (GAO), which published a review of U.S. sanctions programs and their effectiveness in 2019, “These assessments analyze the impacts of specific sanctions on a particular aspect of the sanction’s target—for example, the sanctions’ impact on the target country’s economy or trade.”⁵⁹ OIA, for example, conducts impact assessments before a sanctions designation and after its imposition and may include factors like the target’s U.S.-\n\n⁵⁵ Maurer, *Cyber Mercenaries*,     "[DRAFT – October 2020]\n\nbased assets, global holdings, and interactions with the United States and the potential cascading consequences of a sanctions designation.⁶⁰\n\nHowever, the report acknowledges that “these assessments do not analyze sanctions’ overall effectiveness in achieving broader U.S. policy goals or objectives, such as whether the sanctions are advancing the national security and policy priorities of the United States” (emphasis added).⁶¹ OIA distinguishes between impact and effect in its assessments:\n\nAccording to OIA officials, assessing impact is analyzing the potential or observed effect of the sanction on the target. According to officials, impact can be focused on a singular target or could be broader, such as the impact on the target country’s economy or trade flows. In contrast, OIA views effectiveness as the extent to which a sanctions program is achieving the overall broader policy goals of the sanctions program, such as ultimately altering or deterring specific behaviors of the target or furthering U.S. national security priorities [Emphasis added].⁶²\n\nThe latter considerations come into play during National Security Council-led interagency discussions: The process “allows the U.S. government to draw upon multiple agencies’ inputs and perspectives, and to consider these issues in the larger policy context, because sanctions are often only one element of broader government-wide strategies to achieve U.S. policy goals.”⁶³\n\nEven within government, assessing the effectiveness of sanctions at achieving broader policy goals like deterrence is difficult.
